unnormalised: Okay, here's a Quora post, aiming for a humorous tone and focusing on Emergency Medicine in the Indian context, filled with unnormalized data.
normalised: **Question: What's the craziest thing you've seen in an emergency room in India?**

unnormalised: **Question: What's the craziest thing you've seen in an emergency room in India?**
normalised: Okay, so you wanna know about crazy E-R stories? Buckle up, bhai, because I’ve got a few. Disclaimer: I'm not Doctor Strange, just a humble resident who's seen a few too many "interesting" cases.

unnormalised: Okay, so you wanna know about crazy ER stories? Buckle up, bhai, because I’ve got a few. Disclaimer: I'm not Dr. Strange, just a humble resident who's seen a few too many "interesting" cases.
normalised: Let me preface this by saying, Indian E-Rs are… different. You think you know chaos? Try fitting twenty relatives into a room clearly designed for two, all simultaneously yelling, "Doctor, dekhiye!" Meanwhile, I'm trying to intubate someone. Good times.

unnormalised: Let me preface this by saying, Indian ERs are… different. You think you know chaos? Try fitting 20 relatives into a room clearly designed for 2, all simultaneously yelling, "Doctor, dekhiye!" Meanwhile, I'm trying to intubate someone. Good times.
normalised: One time, a guy came in complaining of chest pain. Classic M-I, right? E-K-G showed something wonky, vitals were all over the place. We’re prepping him for the cath lab, explaining the whole angioplasty thing, and his wife pulls me aside. “Doctor,” she whispers, “can you also check his constipation? He’s been suffering since Diwali.” Constipation during a heart attack? Priorities, madam, priorities! We did manage to treat the heart attack and the constipation eventually.

unnormalised: One time, a guy came in complaining of chest pain. Classic MI, right? EKG showed something wonky, vitals were all over the place. We’re prepping him for the cath lab, explaining the whole angioplasty thing, and his wife pulls me aside. “Doctor,” she whispers, “can you also check his constipation? He’s been suffering since Diwali.” Constipation during a heart attack? Priorities, madam, priorities! We did manage to treat the heart attack and the constipation eventually.
normalised: Then there was the case of the “possessed” uncle. Apparently, a baba had "cured" him of his ailments, but something went wrong. Patient came in foaming at the mouth, yelling about demons and stuff. Turns out, he was just allergic to the baba's "special" herbs. We gave him fifty milligram of diphenhydramine I-V, and he was asking for chai in thirty minutes. The things we see.

unnormalised: Then there was the case of the “possessed” uncle. Apparently, a baba had "cured" him of his ailments, but something went wrong. Patient came in foaming at the mouth, yelling about demons and stuff. Turns out, he was just allergic to the baba's "special" herbs. We gave him 50mg of diphenhydramine IV, and he was asking for chai in 30 mins. The things we see.
normalised: Oh, and I can't forget the guy who walked in with a coconut stuck on his head. Said he was trying a new yoga pose he saw on YouTube. No broken bones, thankfully, but getting that coconut off was a whole other adventure. Let's just say, a hammer, a chisel, and a whole lot of patience were involved.

unnormalised: Oh, and I can't forget the guy who walked in with a coconut stuck on his head. Said he was trying a new yoga pose he saw on YouTube. No broken bones, thankfully, but getting that coconut off was a whole other adventure. Let's just say, a hammer, a chisel, and a whole lot of patience were involved.
normalised: And the countless times people come in saying "Doctor, just a small fever since yesterday," only for their temperature to be one hundred and four degree Fahrenheit. Like, bhai, that's not a "small fever," that's a full-blown inferno! Paracetamol six hundred and fifty milligram becomes my best friend in those moments.

unnormalised: And the countless times people come in saying "Doctor, just a small fever since yesterday," only for their temperature to be 104°F. Like, bhai, that's not a "small fever," that's a full-blown inferno! Paracetamol 650mg becomes my best friend in those moments.
normalised: My senior Doctor Patil always says, "Emergency medicine in India is like a Bollywood movie – drama, comedy, and a whole lot of masala." And honestly, he’s not wrong. You never know what’s going to walk through that door. Maybe it’s an actual emergency, maybe it's just someone who needs a good cup of chai and a nap. Either way, it's never a dull moment. Just another day in the E-R, folks! Come visit us at one A-M; you'll have a fun time.

unnormalised: My senior Dr. Patil always says, "Emergency medicine in India is like a Bollywood movie – drama, comedy, and a whole lot of masala." And honestly, he’s not wrong. You never know what’s going to walk through that door. Maybe it’s an actual emergency, maybe it's just someone who needs a good cup of chai and a nap. Either way, it's never a dull moment. Just another day in the ER, folks! Come visit us at 1 AM; you'll have a fun time.
